chunks.en: Promotion is too difficult, trying a semi-open source approach to operation.
My honest feeling in the half year since [Reqable]( https://reqable.com) was officially released is that promotion is really too difficult, especially overseas promotion.
The domestic market is relatively better because there is no language or cultural barrier; at least there is an audience for writing some technical articles.
In overseas markets, I tried Twitter and ProductHunt, etc., but there was no traffic at all.
If you have the funds to advertise and find an operations team, that's fine, but for independent developers, this cost is unacceptable.
If you are a full-time operator, one person's energy is limited, and the product's feature updates and iterations will inevitably be greatly affected.
In response to this dilemma, my plan is to use a semi-open-source approach and see how it goes.

Here, semi-open source includes two major aspects:
- Module open source.
- Cloud service open source.
Reqable itself is a developer tool. Open source can bring some exposure and traffic to the project, and it can also contribute to the community and grow together, which is a win-win situation.

chunks.en:
## 1. Module Open Source

Open source important modules in the Reqable project. Many of them are currently pain points in the Flutter ecosystem and I spent a lot of effort to complete them. This part of the open-source modules will iterate and grow with the Reqable project.
As long as the Reqable project is alive, these repositories will continue to be maintained and iterated.
Reqable uses componentized development, and many modules exist in the form of separate repositories. The following are all the components of the project.
![image.png]( https://p9-juejin.byteimg.com/tos-cn-i-k3u1fbpfcp/4e1eebd0a24446cc9a52d667ab3b3ada~tplv-k3u1fbpfcp-jj-mark:0:0:0:0:q75.image#?w=1780&h=1316&s=437935&e=png&b=fefefe)

chunks.en:
The first batch of three modules have been open sourced:
- Code editor
- Text highlighting
- python script framework
I will take time to sort out the code and write documents for other modules in the future to help the Flutter ecosystem get better and better!

#### 1.1 Code Editor

Project address: https://github.com/reqable/re-editor
`Re-Editor` is a powerful lightweight text and code editor component that can be used as a simple multi-line text input component or as a code editor with basic functions.
![art01.gif]( https://p9-juejin.byteimg.com/tos-cn-i-k3u1fbpfcp/ff0f7500690149539ebd24e1d4a5aa09~tplv-k3u1fbpfcp-jj-mark:0:0:0:0:q75.image#?w=800&h=629&s=3722598&e=gif&f=276&b=faf7fa)
`Re-Editor` uses a self-drawn rather than control assembly scheme, so it has high performance and supports large file editing.
`Re-Editor` solves many pain points of Flutter's official `TextField` component, and also has the following features:

chunks.zh:

chunks.en:
- Horizontal and vertical two-way scrolling.
- Text syntax highlighting.
- Content folding and unfolding.
- Input prompts and autocompletion.
- Search and replace function.
- Custom context menu.
- Shortcut key support.
- Large text display and editing.
- Display line numbers and focus lines.
- Smart input.

#### 1.2 Text Highlighting

Project address: https://github.com/reqable/re-highlight
`Re-Highlight` is a powerful text syntax highlighting library that can automatically highlight the syntax of a text, just need to define a syntax rule.
Of course, `Re-Highlight` has built-in syntax highlighting rules for dozens of programming languages, and code syntax highlighting can be achieved with just a few lines of code.
![art01.png]( https://p3-juejin.byteimg.com/tos-cn-i-k3u1fbpfcp/611d91ad4c1a4f63bc9bc732a901d603~tplv-k3u1fbpfcp-jj-mark:0:0:0:0:q75.image#?w=1406&h=1064&s=70439&e=png&b=2b2b2b)

The implementation code of `Re-Highlight` is all written in the `Dart` language and translated from the well-known [highlightjs]( https://github.com/highlightjs/highlight.js) project. The implementation ideas and inspiration come from the [highlight.dart]( https://github.com/git-touch/highlight.dart) project (maintenance has been discontinued).

`Re-Highlight` has synchronized the current latest version v11.9.0 of `highlightjs` and verified all test cases. It should be the most powerful text syntax highlighting library in the Flutter ecosystem.

#### 1.3 python Script Framework

Project address: https://github.com/reqable/python-scripting-api

chunks.en: The Python scripting framework currently used by Reqable is basically Python code and does not contribute much to the Flutter community, so I won't introduce it much. Those who are familiar with Python can take a look.

## 2. Cloud Service Open Source

Almost all API-related software currently rely on cloud services for charging, I thought about it too, but I gave up.
I think Reqable needs to make some changes and completely open source the cloud services, mainly considering the following points:
- Data security.

Almost all large-scale enterprises pay attention to data security. It is unrealistic to put very important API data on third-party servers, so many competitors rely on private deployment for charging.
But many small companies or individuals cannot afford the cost of private deployment at all.
So, my idea is to go the other way, cloud services are free and support free deployment, users only need one server.
- Technology stack.

The Reqable project is currently developed by only one person. In addition to developing the client, I also need to do website development, operation promotion, operation and maintenance, customer service, etc. I am really too busy.
Moreover, I can pat my chest and say that I am proficient in the client, which is no problem, but if you ask me to say that I am proficient in the server, that's bullshit.

Regarding the cloud service project, it is still in the planning and preparation stage. Currently, it is tentatively scheduled that [Levi]( https://github.com/monkeyWie) will develop it with me, of course, Levi will lead it, and I would like to thank Levi for his support here.
Project address: https://github.com/reqable/restapi-cloud-server

## Conclusion

Let's work harder this year and let Reqable grow with the community!
If one day, you can't hold on, don't be a so-called 'soft touch' and make the software free and open source.

This is a kind of harm to your former competitors, and also to this already deformed software industry. (Everyone says it's a huge profit for a skin to cost hundreds, and everyone is looking for cracked versions of productivity software.) Labor should be rewarded, it's the world that's wrong!
Damn!

From the perspective of a developer or engineer, I admire the OP very much. He chose Flutter, a technology with an immature ecosystem, and has done a lot of pioneering work on it. If it can be open-sourced, it will be a great contribution to the community.
But friend, to be honest, if you step out of the technical perspective of a developer and consider it from a commercial perspective, this is undoubtedly a failed product,

chunks.en: First of all, there are too many optional solutions for cross-platform. With the performance of modern computers, it is not difficult to quickly create a simple version of Reqable using Electron with front-end mature editors such as Codemirror highlightjs and other ecosystems. There are many API tools on V station, and Postman's Electron-based performance is not slow. For individual developers, rapid development is a very important point.

chunks.zh: ä¸ªäººå¼€å‘è€… æ˜¯å°è€Œç¾ï¼Œèˆ¹å°å¥½æ‰å¤´ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªäº§å“å¤±è´¥äº†ï¼Œèµ¶ç´§æ¢ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªï¼Œsteam ä¸Šå¾ˆå¤šä¸ªäººå°å›¢é˜Ÿçš„å¼€å‘è€…æ¸¸æˆï¼Œæ— ä¸€ä¾‹å¤–ä¸æ˜¯é€‰æ‹©äº† åƒç´ ç­‰ç¾æœ¯éœ€æ±‚å¾ˆå°ï¼Œä»…æ³¨é‡ç©æ³•å¼€å‘ä¸ç¤¾åŒºåé¦ˆçš„ä½œå“ï¼Œåƒ battlebit project zombie ç­‰å¾ˆå¤šä½œå“éƒ½æ˜¯å¦‚æ­¤ï¼Œå…ˆåšä¸€ä¸ªåŸå‹ï¼Œç„¶åæ”¶é›†å¸‚åœºåé¦ˆ è¿›è¡Œè¿­ä»£
chunks.en: Individual developers are small and beautiful, and it's easy to change direction when the boat is small. If this product fails, quickly switch to the next one. Many developer games developed by individual small teams on Steam have without exception chosen pixel graphics and other art with very small demands, and only focus on gameplay development and community feedback. Many works like battlebit project zombie are like this. First create a prototype, then collect market feedback for iteration.

For individual developers, they should consider a product-first approach, first create a usable version, immediately promote it, collect market feedback, and if they find it difficult and the market response is not good, they should consider the next direction instead of sticking to one place.

In addition, for software, don't spend any more money on promotion in the Chinese market. Even a company as big as Microsoft's annual Windows revenue in China is negligible. Why waste your time? If you don't have channels, going overseas is really the first choice - just one person's opinion, for reference only.
Just make it fully open source and charge for the professional version, with the free version being free.

chunks.en: I have an immature idea: 1. Don't open source, 2. The software must be charged, 3. Release a large number of short-term registration codes in the early stage, 4. Release a large number of cracked services online in the early and mid-term, 5. Interrupt some cracked services in the mid-term, 6. Make the cracked service unstable in the later stage, but with very few stable ones.
Brother, you should make some applications for ordinary people.

chunks.en: You can also compare the advantages with competitors on the official website. For example, your app is native, Charles is Java, so the performance is better. Then you support http/3 while others don't. You need to list a form to tell users at a glance what your advantages are.

chunks.zh: ç„¶åå®˜ç½‘å¯ä»¥å¤šå†™ä¸€äº›è‹±æ–‡ blog å†™ä¸€äº›æœ‰ç”¨çš„ http è°ƒè¯•æŠ€å·§ç­‰æŠ€æœ¯æ–‡ç« ï¼Œå†™å¾—å¤šäº†ä»¥å seo ä¼šä¸Šæ¥ï¼Œè¿™åˆä¼šå¸¦æ¥ä¸€æ³¢è‡ªç„¶æµé‡ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯è¿™ä¸ªå‰æœŸæ•ˆæœå¯èƒ½ä¸æ˜æ˜¾ï¼Œè¦åšæŒ
chunks.en: Then you can write more English blogs on the official website, write some useful http debugging tips and other technical articles. After writing more, the SEO will come up, which will bring a wave of natural traffic. However, the effect may not be obvious in the early stage, so you need to persist.
In addition, you can browse the Reddit developer area more often, help others answer questions, but don't do hard advertising, it's easy to get banned.
Stackoverflow and other forums also have the same approach.
It feels difficult for many people to see it on Twitter without a big shot to lead it. It is mainly for publishing information.
The user base is mainly aimed at overseas, domestic users really have no purchasing power, and it is not worth the effort to do it.
It's not easy to make products, OP, keep going, come on!!!
âœŠâœŠâœŠ

If you want to promote overseas, you must use Google Ads. It is very, very difficult to rely on organic traffic. Google can at least bring traffic. If there is a problem with conversion, that is another issue. How should I put it, I think a big mistake for individual developers is: my time is not a cost, but spending money on promotion is a cost.
If you spend 300 on promotion in the early stage and can recover 200, it means the effect is already very good.
Another point is: if it is a tool product, especially for individuals, a one-time purchase is worth considering, and sometimes wrong price positioning will result in more losses.

The subscription system still has its own greed in it, but your audience is a group of stingy programmers ğŸ¶, just like what the V friend said above, there are so many free alternatives (not to mention cracked ones), why use this?
I also downloaded and used yours before, and only opened it once.
In summary: I am not saying that this project is not good, but that it lies in your perception of the current commercial value and actual value (is it worth paying for its target audience?)
How much?) between the misjudgments, the uncomfortable point is here.
And this point can be completely adjusted freely to choose.
To say something controversial: Maybe a 10 yuan buyout would generate more revenue now?
Finally, I personally think that open source is not the solution, and it may even be a bad move.
If it's fully open source, 90% of people in China may reskin and use it for free.
I personally feel that your product is quite good, but from the perspective of a user, it is equivalent to a component rather than a solution to a series of business problems.

Therefore, unless there is no alternative at all, or a wealthy company will choose to pay to use it, but I don't know how much demand there is for your product itself. After several rounds of screening, I feel that the probability of having fewer paying users is is very high.
So I personally feel, shouldn't you start with open source and free use, and then operate by providing enterprise support?
I feel it's a bit difficult for this kind of tool, especially in the domestic environment, if it's not a necessity, no one will really buy it, if the company is willing to spend money, that's fine!
For individuals, it depends on the economic level!

chunks.zh: æˆ‘è§‰å¾—è¿™èƒ½è§£é‡Š LZ çš„é—®é¢˜ã€Œæ¨å¹¿å¤ªéš¾äº†ã€ å’Œ  ã€Œå°è¯•äº† Twitter å’Œ ProductHunt ç­‰ï¼Œå®Œå…¨æ²¡æœ‰æµé‡ã€å› ä¸ºå¤§å®¶å‹æ ¹ä¸çŸ¥é“ä½ è¿™ç©æ„å¹²å˜›çš„ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚
chunks.en: I think this can explain LZ's problems 'promotion is too difficult' and 'I tried Twitter and ProductHunt, etc., but there was no traffic at all' because everyone doesn't know what the hell this thing does....

Or at least you can't immediately see the value at first glance. You need to click a few more links and open the page to understand. The cognitive threshold for a paid product is so high, how can the promotion effect be good?
If there is no improvement, it may not be your problem, you need to consider starting a new project.
Alas, I can still understand the feeling of spending a lot of effort, but not getting the expected exposure.
I used to make products with a self-use mentality and never promoted them, so I didn't feel anything. But once I wanted to promote them, I realized that the world is so big and people are so small.
Marketing and promotion cost money, technology is not important, and it is basically very difficult to turn domestic open source into commercialization.
